com.sap.conn.jco.ext

Interface MessageServerDataProvider


  • public interface MessageServerDataProvider
    JCo defines the MessageServerDataProvider interface to retrieve information about a message server that can be implemented by infrastructure components. At runtime JCo will use the provided implementation to get the information that is stored and managed elsewhere and not by the application using the JCo (separation of concerns). For example, if the message server is stored on an LDAP server the instance method getMessageServerProperties of the interface MessageServerDataProvider needs to get the relevant configuration data from the LDAP server. Applications using the JCoMessageServer, i.e. want to lookup logon groups or application servers of a system, can rely on the fact that this data is managed elsewhere and simply retrieve the data. Main usage might be to simplify the configuration of destinations for ABAP systems, actually a task for the infrastructure embedding development.

    The following properties are supported:

    jco.message_server.hostThe message server host, for which information shall be retrieved. Mandatory.
    jco.message_server.serviceThe message Server service to use for connecting to the message server. Either this property or jco.message_server.system_id needs to be provided.
    jco.message_server.system_idThe system ID of the system the message server belongs to. Either this property or jco.message_server.service needs to be provided.
    jco.message_server.saprouterSAProuter string to use for a message server protected by a firewall, and which hence can only be reached via a SAProuter. Optional.
    Since:
    JCo 3.1.0

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Properties getMessageServerProperties(String messageServerName)
      getMessageServerProperties() should return a properties object that contains a valid subset of the supported properties mentioned above representing the configuration of the given message server.
      void setMessageServerDataEventListener(MessageServerDataEventListener eventListener)

    • Field Detail

      • MESSAGE_SERVER_HOST

        static final String MESSAGE_SERVER_HOST
        The message server host, for which information shall be retrieved. This property is mandatory.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MESSAGE_SERVER_SERVICE

        static final String MESSAGE_SERVER_SERVICE
        The message server service to use for connecting to the message server. Either this property or SYSTEMID(jco.message_server.system_id) needs to be provided. The value should either represent a logical port administrated in /etc/services or should specify the port directly. If both properties do exist, jco.message_server.service will be preferred.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SYSTEMID

        static final String SYSTEMID
        The System ID of the system the message server belongs to. Either this property or MESSAGE_SERVER_SERVICE(jco.message_server.service) needs to be provided. The value being present will cause a lookup of the logical port sapms<> administrated in /etc/services or should specify the port directly.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SAPROUTER

        static final String SAPROUTER
        SAProuter string to use for a message server protected by a firewall, and which hence can only be reached via a SAProuter. The SAProuter string can contain a chain of SAProuters and their port numbers and has the following format:
        (/H/<host>[/S/<port>][/P/<password>])+
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getMessageServerProperties

        Properties getMessageServerProperties(String messageServerName)
        getMessageServerProperties() should return a properties object that contains a valid subset of the supported properties mentioned above representing the configuration of the given message server. null means that the server configuration is not available. In that case JCoException with key JCO_ERROR_RESOURCE will be thrown. The implementation may throw DataProviderException in order to signal severe issues in an existing configuration or some other internal error, like a wrong setup. As a consequence JCoMessageServerFactory.getMessageServer() method throws JCoException with the appropriate key. By other exceptions JCo runtime assume that the destination was not found and generates JCoException with key JCO_ERROR_RESOURCE.
        Parameters:
        messageServerName - the name of the server configuration for which the properties should be returned
        Returns:
        Properties for the message server configuration or null if the server was not found

      • supportsEvents

        boolean supportsEvents()
        Returns true if the implementation can support MessageServerDataEvents that allow a better integration into the JCo runtime resource management. If the implementation cannot support events it should return false. If you're not sure about the ability that your MessageServerDataProvider can guarantee to fire all events you can return false to be on the safe side. Check out MessageServerDataEventListener for details about the events that your MessageServerDataProvider needs to fire when returning true for this method
        Returns:
        whether the implementation supports MessageServerDataEvents completely
        See Also:
        MessageServerDataEventListener

      • setMessageServerDataEventListener

        void setMessageServerDataEventListener(MessageServerDataEventListener eventListener)
        This method sets a MessageServerDataEventListener implemented by JCo that processes the fired events within the JCo runtime.
        The JCo runtime will register only a single MessageServerDataEventListener instance.
        Parameters:
        eventListener - the MessageServerDataEventListener to which configuration events need to be fired
